content:
Posted: March 31
												DCS is a combat flight simulator. It is designed to mimic realistic/authenic combat operations in military aircraft.Lets get this out of the way; you need a joystick (you dont fly planes with joypads!) and likely if you want to get the most of it, you may need to invest in more gear, such as rudder pedals, a throttle and even VR/Headtracking equipment.The DLC aircraft involved have steep learning curves (some more than others) but come with full manuals as well as tutorial missions of varying quality.Its worth pointing out that the "DLC" are not made by the company, but rather are small dev teams that make extra stuff for the game and use DCS as a platform for it. You are not expected to buy all, if any , of the DLCs.You can find reviews for individual aircraft on steam. The different aircraft DLCs are all fill different roles and have different equipment/weapons so you should investigate thorughly before purchase.You will also likely need a very good PC to run this optimally. Also note that there is a seperate non-steam version of the game, CD keys from Steam work for both, but CD keys from DCS's own store DO NOT WORK ON STEAM.

content:
Posted: February 16, 2014
												For those who do not want to read an essay here, I have three valid point for people who could be interested in this simulation game.1. It's free to try.2. It's the best war plane simulator out at the moment as my feelings go.3. Each "DLC" is a whole game on it's own. It's not only added content in the manner of new plane, but it is intended as full game with campaing. All this is then integrated in one world for Multiplayer purposes.And now for those whou would want to read a bit more. :)It's so damn complex it blows my mind. It simulates the whole plane, each part of the machine is simulated in some form. It depends on what dlc you buy but for example the A-10C or KA-50 (and others too) have fully clickable cockpits and simulated on board computers. You can do everything a real pilot could do. With combination of really powefull mission editor anything is possible.You get whole campaings for selected planes and even in the free to play basic package you can run a campain with SU-25 plane. Now when you combine this with multiplayer and really superb community, you get a package that can keep you entertained for years. Mercenary mission with your friends or with you "clan" are only the top of the iceberg here.I have only one con here, the game is really demanding. You will NEED to have a 64bit machine and highend CPU/GPU to really enjoy high details. This will maybe be solved when a new engine will be released (it's planed for this year) but I wouldn't put high hopes for this. Its mainly focused on adding DX11 support.

												DCS World is the best Combat Flight and Armored Simulator on the market, you really cannot find anything else better, especially for the price.I fly Lockheed Martin's Prepar3D, which is a professional flight simulator, but the Combat is unlocked for $700 and is really only intended for the Military. Combined Arms alone for $5.99 is worth it because you're getting the best tank and armored simulator you'll ever find, period.The UH-1 Huey is the only one I've seen with such detail and you would normally pay close to $80 for something like that for Microsoft FSX, Prepar3D or X-Plane.  So, for sale price of $15, its another steal!If you ever wanted to try a Flight Simulator, this is the one for you because the tutorials give a much lower learning curve.

content:

												This is amazing, its not for all tho, its a simulator not your average game like warthunder, so the learning curve is like tryin to learn to pilot the aircraft in real life lol, ive spent hours reading operating manuals & watching youtube tutorials/tips, just to get a basic understanding on operating the aircrafts flight controls, modes, radar, navigation, weapons, countermeasures, etc etc... aswell as trying not to blackout from G-force in hard manuvers, ive still got a long way to go and a tone to learn but loving it all despite the work. I run on max settings and the graphics are amazing, at the minimum you need a joystick to play, i went cheap myself with a logitech 3d pro, but i know alot that have a full setup with seperate pedals/thottle controls which does help but i dont think its absolutely necessary, i dont have my own yet because of the cost but id definitely recommend a trackIR system to use in DCS, because in a dogfight its so easy to lose sight of your target, in my case anyway lol, by trying to look around with the keyboard while possibly evading a missle or trying to follow an evading target that maybe slipping in and out of your radar.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 16, 2016
												DCS World is an unapolegetically realistic Combat Aircraft Sim. You know how you have all those dials, gauges, switches and stuff in your typical aircraft cockpit? Well in DCS they all actually mean something and have ramifications as to how your aircraft performs.I can't stress this point enough, DCS (Which stands for "Digital Combat Simulator") is a SIMULATOR. That means that it's less focused on traditional game design paradigms and more concerned with realism. Sure it's probably not 100% Realistic, I've never piloted an aircraft in my life (and never will due to medical reasons), so a real pilot would probably be able to pick at things. That's fine, to my understanding it's about as close as you can get with modern technology.Yes this means a steep learning curve, ESPECIALLY due to the fact that not all aircraft operate the same. They have different start-up procedures, binded to different keys (or differently placed buttons), different avionics systems, and different controls.I know that this is a turn off to most of you, but I'm giving it a thumbs up for one simple reasonIf you are just plain curious it's free!Yeah yeah there's a buttload of DLC which has most of the content, but If you try it and it's not your thing, no harm no foul, but if you take the time to actually play it, slowly learn how to operate your aircraft, and have the patience, focus, and willingness to try, try again, you are in for a treat!Because once you get used to it, flying these things is really freakin AWESOME! These things FEEL like jets, and to a degree, you are crossing miles of (virtual) landscape in pretty much a blink of an eye, and delivering a projectile at even greater distances in some cases with avionic-assisted precision! Just an awesome feeling I think!Also for those who like attention to detail, some of the DLC planes (including a free one you get, a T51 Prop-plane) actually have the ability to click on individual buttons/turn dials and cranks alongside the binded keypresses. Which is really neat!*Just remember though you are buying planes for an extra simulation experience, it's more of a self-study than anything unless of course you need to round out roles because I'm sure Ground attack/CAS isn't going to be what everyone wants to do in a Combat aircraft sim.

content:
Posted: January 14
												I would highly recommend this sim for anybody with a passion for aviation!Make sure your system can handle it tho, as it can be very taxing on your cpu in multiplayer and in large missions.The most interesting things about DCS are (for me):- Lots of extremely high fidelity modules (expensive, yes... but quality comes at a price)!-The outstanding flightmodels; the helicopters and the warbirds are fantastic ( those are the machines I spend the most time in)!- The simulation of the systems of the different aircrafts is on a level you will not find anywhere else!- Lots of interesting multiplayer servers!- ....- And a great community!Try the (free) base game... and if you like it, maybe buy some of the modules. Be careful tho, as from experience I can say... once you start buying them, it will be difficult to stop :PI could tell you many more things about it, but that would cause me to write a whole essay... and I'm not in the mood for that ;)

DCS has a great design team and third party partners to keep this sim up and running till we all die from old age. I recommend this sim to serious gamers who want a learning curve, who want a rewarded feeling when you win an air battle because its tough. A person who likes to fly using ILS during a storm or wants to utilize their instruments because they work. Realism and updates to realism is what this sim is about. A community of folks who will help you learn your way until you one day are helping another learn to fly, fight, land in a shot up jet under tedious conditions. Enjoy DCS, I do!!

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 8, 2015
												DCS World is, quite simply, the combat flight simulator that I've been waiting for. From the get-go there's one thing that I have to make absolutely clear: *This simulator is FUN!If you are an aircraft enthusiast and always had the dream to fly, then this is your best bet - that is, if you are not a real pilot or if becoming one is not an option. The only things you won't feel when you strap yourself into a DCS World cockpit, are the G-forces. The instructional training missions are on-point and helpful, the missions challenging and fun, the learning curve steep and frustrating at times, the manuals as thick as a medical encyclopedia - but you know what, it's the package. I remember the days when I played Jane's USNF 97 and Microsoft Combat Flight Simulator, which were games that I couldn't get enough of. DCS World has replaced them with the same amount of, or even more, fun.Simply brilliant.

content:
Posted: August 3, 2014
												Probably the best and most realistic flight simulator on the market today. And on top of that you get to blow stuff up! What else could you ask for?-Modules I have tried out-A-10C: Most thorough flight simulation I have ever flown. From what I can tell all of the flight systems, computers, and avionics are operated exactly how they would be in real life and also have the same advantages, faults, and limitations. That being said starting it up from a cold start is always rewarding (If you do not mess something up along the way) but also very braintwisting. I have a much higher level of respect for the pilots who fly them for not just smashing their heads into a pulp trying to get the plane started up. The flight dynamics are exceptional also, and it's intricate weapon systems are very fun to blow up Russian tanks with.UH-1H Huey: I have flown hundreds of flight simulators, but they were all with fixed winged aircraft. I could not find a better way to learn the art of helicoptering from this jem. The Huey is a historical legend for it's service during the vietnam war among others, and its later civilian services that still continue to this day. It sure flys like a legend too, you will not find many complicated computer systems you have to spend days learning about in it. Starting it up is simply turning the right combination of knobs and switches. Flying it is not real challenge after spending enough time to get used to it. You will learn to hover it and land in the most obscure places possible. It's flight dynamics like any other DCS title is exceptional. From the basic increase in lift as the helicopter gains horizontal velocity to the more uncommon stalling. The developers really show pride in their work as many other aerodynamic effects are modelled in such as rotors breaking due to a high RPM and negative G environment. The weapon systems are really fun to mess around with, there is really not much to them apart from shooting a minigun in the direction of your enemies and watching the carnage.Flaming Cliffs 3: A great module for the less experienced flight simmers or casual player. Instead of focusing on a single high quality aircraft the developers worked on a great variety of more mediocre modelled aircraft. There are no interactable cockpits here besides closing the canopy. Apart from that, the planes are still modelled well for the status quo of a flight simulation. The F-15 included however has a very well modelled aerodynamics system that blows all the others in this module out of the water. Even though this module is much lower quality than the other titles, it is still very fun. And lets face it, cheaper too for the amount of content and variety it has.I would reccomend for more veteran flight simulators to stay away from this module as most of the planes are not very well modelled and some are just dumbed down versions of other aircraft in the simulation like the A-10A and SU-25.The F-15 is the plane that makes the module worth it, and as it is now only 10$ I reccomend just buying that instead of paying $50 on Flaming cliffs 3. The only reason I got it was it was on sale and was the same price of the F-15 at the time, so it just made more sense to buy all of Flaming cliffs 3 instead of just one aircraft included in it that was the same price as it. Free aircraft:TF-51: The TF-51 is a real fun plane for aerobatics if that is your cup to tea. It has a pretty good flight model and has a fully clickable and interactable cockpit, its flight and internal systems are just as well modelled.SU-25T: Although it is not exceptionally well modelled with the fact it does not have an interactable cockpit, the SU-25T is one of the most combat effective ground attack planes provided in the simulation. You will have plenty hours of free fun learning the plane's systems, flight characteristics and employing it's weapon systems successfully. A great plane to introduce new pilots or players to the simulation.

content:
Posted: March 6, 2014
												There'a a lot to say about this game. Look for the TL;DR at the end.This is probably the best deal on Steam. You don't have to spend a dime and you get access to an increadiable game. It's a full blown simulator, so expect a decent learning curve, especially with the weapons and navigation systems, but the game comes with a full compliment of interactive tutorials. After a good Saturday of playing, I had a good handle on everything and could freely enjoy playing. Mastering those skills is something else entirely, but of course, part of the fun.Re-playability, for me this is probably the most important part of any game and for me, this game offers a lot of replayability, if your willing to put in some work. The game comes with a handful of missions, but the Mission Edditor allows you to create your own custom missions and it's a POWERFUL tool. Create a vast and complex mission or even campaign or a simple scenario for you to practice your shooting skills. If your savy, you can even use Lua to write your own scripts and really add complexity.You don't need additional hardware for this game, but a good flight-stick at the minimum will make the game a lot more fun. If you have some cash and want to get a HOTAS stick and throttle, that's probably the best way to go. I don't have one and don't plan on getting one and I'm quite happy with that. Certain actions take me a bit longer, because I have to hit CTL-ALT something.  TL;DR - If you're looking for a combat flight simulator, this is the best I know of. If you have some money to spend I highly recomend the A10-C add-on. Expect a decent learning curve with a high pay off. A lot of re-playability with the custom mission editor. Maybe get a flight stick.10/10

content:
Posted: June 23, 2015
												Original Review ~20 hours logged:""""""I would love nothing more then to give this game a good review, it is by far the most realistic flight sim i have played. That being siad its also a huge disapointment dlc wise. I have bought both the f-15c and a-10c (4.99$ and 9.99$ i think) dlcs and expected to get a full flight expeirience with each craft. the f-15c has no training missions which makes the craft absolutly worthless to me. the A-10 has a wonderful training program but they skimped out on any decent content campaing wise. thats only 2 of the 250$ worth of dlc and if they expect me to pay 49.99$ for a single plane they better ace the cheaper ones to show me what im getting. because of this the A-10 will be the only dlc ship i ever fly and my review went from one of praisal to one of disapiontment."""""Reached 69 hours and got my first MP kill followed imediatly by my second... Followed imediatly by me spinning out of control due to excessive dive and improper nose trim adjustments.This Game is amazing. My review was at i time when i thought i understanded this game. I've logged a decent amount of time since then and fell in love with the Su27, and this flight simulator is absolutly fantastic. My advice is not to make rash judgments, take the time to learn everything properly and Multiplayer makes the game ( Although you will be blown up a lot ). Ask questions If you need help, obviously not everyone is willing to help but this game seems to have a fairly positive community.Also you can find a flight manual for the f-15 in the file location and there are plenty of tutorials on the web.

Posted: September 29, 2016
												This game is an absolute gem. DCS World is a true flight simulator that even incorporates modern AA and AG combat into it. I am absolutely positive that this is the best flight simulator made to date. Just to address one concern of others. When you download DCS, you recieve a free aircraft, the Su-25T (Frogfoot). It's a very capable aircraft and enjoyable to fly. Where people get upset is that there are lots of DLC module aircraft that you have to pay for. The thing people don't understand is that this game is made by a business and they have to make money. When they spend 3 years developing a module, a 2.99 price tag isn't going to cut it. The fact that they sell some of these for $10, especially with the low playerbase of the game is astounding. Instead of complaining that you have to pay for these aircraft, praise them for being so generous.EDIT: For some reason DCS only counts the time in game on my steam account as the time the game is launching. I really have at this time (30/09/16) approximately 230 hours.

												Pros- possibly has more types of plane than any other military flight simulation- ok learning curve for flaming cliff package, you can get into dogfight in 1 hour- nice tutorial for most of the planesCons- no real dynamic campaign and the original campaign is not attractive enough, haven't tried the dlc campaigns though- mp gameplay is also a bit boring if you are flying solo, most of the mp servers are just simple dogfighting/ground attack without real missions and planningConclusionIt is a great simulator for military aircrafts, very precise and realistic reproduction of flying/weapons delivery procedure. content:
Posted: August 3, 2013
												This is the most awesome thing in the world since Fire&Beer and whoever doesn't play this 24/7 has NEVER lived!edit 23.12.2014; Been playing DCS:World now since 09/2012 and there hardly goes by a week I don't take time to fly for a few hours. Make no mistake, this is a flightsimulator at heart, no GAME. Even if there are planes with a very low learning curve, for the full 'DCS experience' you should read or watch the manual/tutorials.edit 01.07.2016: Still at it! With 1.5 & 2.0 we have lot's of new stuff. Best 2.0 feature: Collidable tree's!There are planes/helis for casuals, hardcore flightsim-nerds and of course newbies. If you want to fly the A-10C and still find new things to learn after two years (~600 pages manual) or a Su-25T where you can learn how to fly & kill stuff in a few minutes with a tutorial is completly up to you.WW2 era is progressing at a quick pace, at the time of writing there are two very active WW2 dedicated servers with fun& sometimes realistic scenarios although the allys are quite a little outgunned at the current point with only the P-51D Mustang, but that will change very soon.Don't expect any balancing to spare your feelings, if an engine is more powerful IRL it will be in DCS.I own all the current released DCS modules and promise you every full DCS module + FC3 is worth the money. No starforce DRM, buggy patch or delay development can destroy the immense fun I got out of this. This sim is the next  best experience to flying a plane RL we can get on the civillian market right now. X-plane/FSX/P3D have just inferior flight models and I have yet so see anyone of those do a comfortable 6dof-friendly & clickable cockpit like in DCS.Pro-Tip: You can fly the Su-25T & TF-51D for free! The latter is nearly exactly the same as the P-51D Mustang, only unarmed. With the Mustang you can really see what this Sim is about, Su-25T look what FC3 may be like.

DCS World: a great flying simulator, and it's FREE!I'll write down a fast review, because I haven't got much time to spend on this.I'm playing this game as my main flight sim. Is the game fun at the beginning? No, not really. At the start it was just frustrating. The commands are hard to learn, and not intuitive. I couldn't turn on the plane.Then I got it, and started playing. I liked it. So I went to the store and bought a flying joystick.Logitech Attack 3(fun fact: I bought it for CHF 5.- (€5 circa) NEW!)I bought the F-15C Eagle too. (not fun fact: I bought it and the same day it went 50% off. ♥♥♥♥ my life)It's a really good game, the physics are really realistic and playing with friends is fun! Formation flying and dogfights are really satisfying.Pros and consPros:-good graphics-good planes-good dedicated servers and community-physics are good!Cons:-learning curve-a really hard flight sim, don't bother downloading if you're not looking over to spend time on learning how to fly a planeFinal rating:Well, I rate it 9/10 'cause it's a really good sim overall.AS I SAID, let go of this game if you're not gonna invest time in learning it. It's not install&shoot. NOT. AN ARCADE. GAME.I've seen negative reviews saying "too realistic". Dumbasses downloading a flight SIMULATOR and whining about it being what it is supposed to be.EDIT 29/04/2016: The "switching windows" bug is gone, and now the interface is really smooth and good!

Posted: January 21, 2015
												The basic DCS World is not very exciting, but once you start adding the DLC aircraft then this quickly turns into one of the most amazing flight simulator I've played.I don't think it's very fun to try flying these aircraft with a mouse and keyboard, maybe if you enable "Game Mode". I own every DLC released to date but I mostly fly the UH-1 and the A-10C, using the Thrustmaster Warthog HOTAS joystick and throttle, the Saitek Pro Combat rudder pedals and TrackIR from NaturalPoint. Yes, that's a lot of gear (and advertisement), but the DLC cockpits are SO well made, it's amazing!Speaking of DLCs, this game does not feel like a DLC scam. The companies that have made the aircraft in the "single aircraft" DLCs have done amazing jobs. Fully interactive cockpits with "six degrees of freedom" movement (you can move in three dimentions inside the cockpit) make for a very immersive experience. The personal reward of being able to cold-start an A-10C, taxi to the runway, take off, navigate to your destination and safely land again is a great feeling!This is to WarThunder what Arma3 is to Battlefield; it's a step-up in realism for the "gamers" that are looking for more than bunny-jumping, headshots and "lulz".

content:
Posted: March 18, 2015
												A few of my friends have been playing this for a while, and I've been dying to get it. I recently built a decent computer and decided to take the plunge into throwing hours of my life at the screen.  I bought the F-15 module just to try it out, and although disappointed the F-16 has not been modeled (Yet), the Eagle is a stellar combat platform. Coming from a background in civil aviation and being type rated on Cessna 172XP, I can vouch for how realistic the flight model feels. It really (to the extent that my controls can convey) feels like you are being buffeted by wind at low speeds, you can "feel" the aircraft as is starts to lose lift, and after a few hours you start being able to read the aircraft, when it is about to stall, the best roll to turn, AoA for climbing at the edge, you become one with the aircraft. Switching from one plane to another really throws your head for a loop. They've really got the effect of feeling what the aircraft is doing damn near perfect. I don't think even FSX models ground effect as realistically (read: scary as F***) as this game does. It truly is a simulation. Pull the stick back and cut the throttle, as the aircraft starts to shake and the wing starts to dip, adrenaline kicks in. It is unreal. I've never gotten such a physical response from a game before. The weight of the weapon and fuel payload is completely dynamic. I found myself flying touch-and-go landings for hours, working towards getting my glide slope and flare *just* right, only to restart and realize my pitch angles and approach speeds had to be entirely different from when I ended the last time, due to being fully loaded again. This is not a game you can pick up and start dominating in within a few minutes. You need to dedicate hours upon hours learning the airframe you want to excel in, and stick to it. It will frustrate you, it will make you never want to hold a flight stick again, but once you get your first kill, or the first time you successfully take on fuel from a flying tanker, the amount of excitement you feel is incredible. Getting sweaty palms from holding the aircraft perfectly in formation so as to not get a fuel boom in your turbine is great. Getting a radar contact at 80 miles, and have to watch his blip get closer and closer, until finally entering the weapon effective range had me on the edge of my seat. I find myself running through my last sortie in my head while I'm at work, thinking of what I could have done differently, better tactics to use, strategies to try. It is amazingly addicting.    I've logged 14 hours over the last few days, and I see myself putting in quite a few more late nights, flying hundreds of sorties. I haven't even delved into the online world yet. I am hesitant simply because I know there are thousands of people online who would make me look like I've never even flown a paper airplane before, and I don't want to make a fool of myself. Yet. :)I think the only downside to this simulator is quite simply how steep the learning curve is. I'm sure there will be quite a few people who can't take off, get angry and say this game is broken. Take it slow, do the lessons, and most importantly, READ THE MANUAL! Yeah, most of them are close to 200 pages, but like I said earlier, your first kill will make that completely worth it.I would highly suggest that if you are an aviation fanatic, like a challenge, and want to get as close as you can to pushing the throttles to the forward stop in a variety of combat aircraft without joining the military, get this game. I can only sit back and wonder how they are going to improve DCS:W in their second iteration, because from my perspective, the mechanics of it are spot on.

												Amazing game a must have, If you love Fighter simulators then your in for a treat, it has a big learning curve to it, but all in good time and practice you become a great fighter10/10Edit:That was my past review I thought well now Ive gotten the gyst of it let re-review it. inb4 long♥♥♥♥♥read hope it helpsFirstly you do not need to have a HOTAS Joystick and Throttle or rudder pedals, its a bit more difficult but its still do able. The First im gonna say 50+ Hours I played with my Logitech Extreme 3D Pro $40 Joystick (I live in Australia), I played Su-25T, FC3 and Partially A-10C. I played them all comfortably the only thing that was needed was to remember more keybindings etc for the A-10c and Su-25T, FC3 all the important stuff was able to be bound to my joystick regardless the point is, for a free simulator that has a amazing engine and crazy realism to it all you need is $40 for a joystick and any extra money for modules and you can play. I bought the HOTAS Warthog around 60 hours into the game still dont have rudder pedals but thats fine I just use the 'Z' and 'X' keys thats it, if you love Military aircraft and you plan on enlisting one day then install this game, do it you wont regret it, if you love a challenge this is the game for you. To lay it out ill put some pros and cons below.Pros:- The SU-25T and PF-51 Mustang are Free- The best Military Aviation Simulator on the market- Aircraft are being added all the time for example Leatherneck Sims is working on a F-14 Tomcat model which is gonna be amazing- All eras of Aircraft from 40's all the way to current.- FC3 is more of a easier version but still in relation to the realism flight.- Plenty of Single Player missions and servers to play on.- Graphics are beautiful on this game as well as the sound.- Performance is good even in MP, I have a 8 year old GPU and a Quad core CPU and with come custom settings and Mirrors off I get in SP 40-60 FPS and in MP 30-40 FPS- If you buy it from the website or steam you can still play with eachotherCons:- It has a big learning curve- There are only a few tutorial missions for standalone modules, there is no Tutorials on FC3, F-86F, Hawk only to name a few.- SP missions do tend to bug out sometimes not all the time- In the same sense that it is cheap it is also expensive with each module going for about $40+- not all of the modules are on Steam, the ones on the DCS website are available on there for a while before it gets released on Steam. For example 14 out of the 17 available modules are available on Steam not including terrains or campaigns.- You need Rudder pedals for rotary aircraft I tried and wasn't able to fly without themSo in short this is a great simulator it has its cons but its so worth it for the pros of the game. Some advice if you are thinking about spending $500 on a HOTAS Warthog, ask your self this are you going to make Simming a hobby or is it going to sit on your desk and collect dust? Simming is a expensive hobby so unless your going to use it dont bother. If you want to try the game out use a cheap joystick like the 3D Pro, if you are going to play moderately grab yourself a X55 Rhino it has HOTAS Functionality and so I have heard its a good joystick, if you know you are going to sim a fair bit at least 3-4 times a week and put hours into the game get the HOTAS Warthog and some rudderpedals. Also if you see the modules F-15C, SU-27, SU-25 and A-10A for DCS dont bother they are $10 each they are all included in Flamming Cliffs 3 Module as well as the MIG-29A, MIG-29S and SU-33.So do I recommend the game to everyone? Yes give it a try you may like itFor aviation enthusiasts? Why haven't you already installed thisFor people who want to make simming a hobby? Go buy a HOTAS and modules to your likingI absolutely love this Simiulator and if you love Military Aircraft you will too, I hoped this long♥♥♥♥♥essay helped in your desicion.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 18, 2015
												A few of my friends have been playing this for a while, and I've been dying to get it. I recently built a decent computer and decided to take the plunge into throwing hours of my life at the screen.  I bought the F-15 module just to try it out, and although disappointed the F-16 has not been modeled (Yet), the Eagle is a stellar combat platform. Coming from a background in civil aviation and being type rated on Cessna 172XP, I can vouch for how realistic the flight model feels. It really (to the extent that my controls can convey) feels like you are being buffeted by wind at low speeds, you can "feel" the aircraft as is starts to lose lift, and after a few hours you start being able to read the aircraft, when it is about to stall, the best roll to turn, AoA for climbing at the edge, you become one with the aircraft. Switching from one plane to another really throws your head for a loop. They've really got the effect of feeling what the aircraft is doing damn near perfect. I don't think even FSX models ground effect as realistically (read: scary as F***) as this game does. It truly is a simulation. Pull the stick back and cut the throttle, as the aircraft starts to shake and the wing starts to dip, adrenaline kicks in. It is unreal. I've never gotten such a physical response from a game before. The weight of the weapon and fuel payload is completely dynamic. I found myself flying touch-and-go landings for hours, working towards getting my glide slope and flare *just* right, only to restart and realize my pitch angles and approach speeds had to be entirely different from when I ended the last time, due to being fully loaded again. This is not a game you can pick up and start dominating in within a few minutes. You need to dedicate hours upon hours learning the airframe you want to excel in, and stick to it. It will frustrate you, it will make you never want to hold a flight stick again, but once you get your first kill, or the first time you successfully take on fuel from a flying tanker, the amount of excitement you feel is incredible. Getting sweaty palms from holding the aircraft perfectly in formation so as to not get a fuel boom in your turbine is great. Getting a radar contact at 80 miles, and have to watch his blip get closer and closer, until finally entering the weapon effective range had me on the edge of my seat. I find myself running through my last sortie in my head while I'm at work, thinking of what I could have done differently, better tactics to use, strategies to try. It is amazingly addicting.    I've logged 14 hours over the last few days, and I see myself putting in quite a few more late nights, flying hundreds of sorties. I haven't even delved into the online world yet. I am hesitant simply because I know there are thousands of people online who would make me look like I've never even flown a paper airplane before, and I don't want to make a fool of myself. Yet. :)I think the only downside to this simulator is quite simply how steep the learning curve is. I'm sure there will be quite a few people who can't take off, get angry and say this game is broken. Take it slow, do the lessons, and most importantly, READ THE MANUAL! Yeah, most of them are close to 200 pages, but like I said earlier, your first kill will make that completely worth it.I would highly suggest that if you are an aviation fanatic, like a challenge, and want to get as close as you can to pushing the throttles to the forward stop in a variety of combat aircraft without joining the military, get this game. I can only sit back and wonder how they are going to improve DCS:W in their second iteration, because from my perspective, the mechanics of it are spot on.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 17, 2014
												If you're looking for an arcade-y flight sim similar to Ace Combat or War Thunder, this isn't it. But if you're like me and you wanted a rich flying experience, DCS World brings that and much more to the table. I don't have nearly as many hours logged as some of the reviewers here but I can safely say that I'm hooked on this sim. In my opinion, the two must-have paid modules are Flaming Cliffs 3 and A-10C. FC3 is the bridge between the "arcade" and pure simulation aspects of DCS World, though it's by no means an arcade game at all. My preferred aircraft in FC3, the F-15, still requires a good deal of practice to get used to flying and fighting in, but once you have developed some proficiency with it, it's fantastic. It's always satisfying to go head-to-head with human opponents and actually have to work in order to get a kill.On the other hand, the A-10C is pure simulation. There's a lot of buttons and switches to learn, but if you do the training missions, you'll have a good foundation to work with. Do them a couple of times just to be sure you have a basic knowledge of what to do in certain situations and with certain weapons and flight systems.A couple of caveats: you can get a basic flight stick, but a HOTAS (Hands On Throttle And Stick) is highly recommended. I use a Saitek X55 (which has its own interesting quirks but I digress) but there are some others out there on the market. If money's no object, I'd recommend the Thrustmaster Warthog. Whichever you choose, make sure the stick and throttle have buttons for you to bind some of the critical controls to (landing gear, airbrakes, countermeasures, etc.) The last thing you want to be doing in a dogfight is taking your hands off the throttle and stick to mash buttons on the keyboard to deploy chaff or flares.Having some sort of headtracking peripheral wil also go a long way to improving how immersed you are in the sim. It can be a bit of a pain having to use the mouse to look for enemies, especially if you're in an air-to-air fight. Another example is in A-10C, during a cold start, there's a couple of switches behind the throttle that you have to flip. These are normally obscured from the default viewing position, but if you have a TrackIR or something similar, you can "lean" down, see, and flip them accordingly. That said, DCS World is probably my absolute favorite game across the board. There's always something to do. You just have to be willing to put in the time to learn to fly.

Posted: June 27, 2014
												It is an amazing simulator, probably the best one out there. I bought the Flaming Cliffs 3 Addon so far and it is tons of joy, it is quite a bit challenging to learn the ropes if you are new to simulators (like I am) but once you get into it, you'll have a lot of fun.   Russian and American planes both have different avionics, making them feel different (and as such you have to learn to use both separately). Still trying to get used to the radar, but locking on and firing with missiles is piece of cake once you learn how to (watching the tutorials for both russians and americans twice did the trick for me).So, all in all, if you are looking for a very realistic simulator, definitely give this one a shot because the basic game is free and has the Su-25 and the TF-51 in it, which by themselves already offer a lot of fun, and from there you can decide whether you want to get into the game more.P.S. If you ever see me in a multiplayer game (I still have yet to play it), go easy on me. I'll most likely be an easy target for you anyways :P

content:
Posted: September 12, 2014
												Hugely detailed sim, can't stress it enough how much I'm in love with the DCS series of aircraft simulators thus far. The advanced flight model aircraft with fully functional cockpits are about as close to the real thing as you can get without actual military sim equipment. And ED along with other 3rd party devs are continually releasing new aircraft to build more possibilities for the game and it's multiplayer. And having this single platform bring all previous and upcoming sims into one environment is genius.And the base platform comes with two free sims, a Su-25T (rivals A-10 Warthog with it's massive arsenal, it's powerful and easily capable to be able to hop right into multiplayer without spending a dime) and a trainer version of the P-51D, for aerobatic fun.Note that this pretty much expects you to have a joystick, don't expect to play on a keyboard, unless you buy the Combined Arms pack that lets you take control of vehicles and fight it out on the ground.Absolutely no reason not to give it a try. Unless you hate planes or something. But what kind of monstrous, awful person actually hates planes

												If you are keen on flight sims then DCS World is a must have.  I'm interested in WW2 aviation and enjoy the DCS experience.  If you are new to flight sims and want to try a "propellor" sim I would recommend "il2 Battle of Stalingrad" before trying DCS.  DCS would probably be too over-whelming for the first time flight sim player.  BOS would give a more satisfying experience.But for the flight sim grognard there is a lot to like about DCS.  Fully clickable cockpits, very nice flight model, competitive AI and the option of jets.  Plus DCS WW2 is coming soon.Good support on the DCS forums.

I do recommend this to any Combat Simmer that has had real flight sim flying and or is a real pilot looking for Sim combat fun.

content:
Posted: January 11, 2015
												This game is simply amazing. I found this game browsing Steam and decided to give it a try. Given that the SU-25T module is free, I figured that it would be low quality and very limited in its playability. The complete opposite is true! The plane proved a pleasure to fly and I thoroughly enjoyed the challenge offered in mastering the plane. The first time I was able to take off from an airfield, find a tank convoy, attack it successfully, and return to base, I was sold. The game sucked me in and I knew I had to buy some new modules. I decided on the A-10A, F-15C, and SU-27 modules. The planes are beautifully modeled and each one offers a unique approach to their specific role. Although the learning curve is steep (especially steep for the A-10C, I hear), the reward of mastering an aircraft is unmatchable in comparison to any other game I've ever played. The game offers fantastic gameplay for those who are into heavy ground-pounding aircraft like the A-10 or SU-25 and for those of us who dream of being the Top Gun and dominating the sky. I haven't tried any of the helicopter modules, but they're next on my list. Those looking for a challenging game and are military jet fans should definitely try this game. 10/10!

												This game is a great combat simulator! The best i've seen in years. This game will test your awareness and reaction to the combat enviornment. You have to pay attention to fuel , radar contact , incoming missiles , BVR targets (Beyond Visual Range) , SAMS , and much more! Trust me , you wont regret getting this game.

content:
Posted: February 27, 2015
												This is THE BEST combat sim I've ever played. The realism is outstanding and it's fun to play over and over. The amount of variables that can be controlled is almost overwhelming at first, but in a good way. The whole setup allows for a whole lot of freedom to plan an attack or a counter attack or to pretty much fight the enemy anyway you want. I really can't wait to see what they have coming in the future. It's hard to find a game that I truly get excited about these days but this is definitely one of them. They even have aerial refueling. Man is it hard but that's part of the fun. The only issue I have, and it's not really about the game design itself, is that I wish there were more American combat aircraft. I hope it's in the works but I'd really like to fly an AH-64 on a sortie in the Middle East or fly an F-22 and bomb the crap out of ISIS. There really is almost an unlimited amount of expansion as the creators didn't box themselves in with this game. The game is totally outstanding, even for Russians. :) :) (BTW that's why there are so many Russian aircraft)

content:
Posted: January 13, 2015
												Great flight sim that involves combat aircraft. If you're curious about flying and if you'd like something like this DCS being free is a great point to give it a shot. You're only able to fly the SU-25T which is a clunky russian jet, and the TF-51D which is an unarmed version of the P-51. Any other aircraft you'll find yourself having to pay for them to be able to fly; but they are very much so worth the money. They painstakingly recreate these aircraft with all of the bells and whistles of the real deal, down to the weapon loadouts, the systems on the aircraft and even the instrument panels are accurate to the real deal and if you so choose you can click the switches and simulate pressing them yourself rather than pressing a keybind on your keyboard.Controllers/joysticks are easy to configure and the mission editor lets you configure custom missions to fly as well as the multiplayer is fun. If flying is your thing, or could be your thing definatly give DCS a shot.

content:
Posted: September 19, 2014
												Amazing Sim. With so many modules available and more coming this game is fantastic. The realism is amazing and once you get more familiarized with the controls and settings you can easily spend countless hours flying. Recently picked up the A-10C Warthog module and it is absolutely incredible. The realism and immersion is through the roof with total control in the cockpit of pretty much every switch / knob / dial and button.  I'm looking forward to and hoping for an F-18 module that has the same kind of control and realism in the future as that is one of my favorite aircraft of all time. Can't wait to see what they make next!Edit* 3/23/15Still flying in this amazing sim. With DCS 2.0 (hopefully) around the corner, it just keeps getting better! Picked up the F-86, MiG21BiS, FW-190D, P-51 and FC3 which includes the F-15 and Su-27 advanced flight models and still having a blast with it. Hoping that a sale comes soon on steam so I can get the rest of the ones I'm missing.Mission editor = countless ways to enjoy the sim and get better at flying in different roles/situations. Great Devs/community that keep the spirit alive and lots of resources out there to educate yourself in the ways of military aviation.  KEEP UP THE GREAT WORK!!!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 17, 2014
												If you're looking for an arcade-y flight sim similar to Ace Combat or War Thunder, this isn't it. But if you're like me and you wanted a rich flying experience, DCS World brings that and much more to the table. I don't have nearly as many hours logged as some of the reviewers here but I can safely say that I'm hooked on this sim. In my opinion, the two must-have paid modules are Flaming Cliffs 3 and A-10C. FC3 is the bridge between the "arcade" and pure simulation aspects of DCS World, though it's by no means an arcade game at all. My preferred aircraft in FC3, the F-15, still requires a good deal of practice to get used to flying and fighting in, but once you have developed some proficiency with it, it's fantastic. It's always satisfying to go head-to-head with human opponents and actually have to work in order to get a kill.On the other hand, the A-10C is pure simulation. There's a lot of buttons and switches to learn, but if you do the training missions, you'll have a good foundation to work with. Do them a couple of times just to be sure you have a basic knowledge of what to do in certain situations and with certain weapons and flight systems.A couple of caveats: you can get a basic flight stick, but a HOTAS (Hands On Throttle And Stick) is highly recommended. I use a Saitek X55 (which has its own interesting quirks but I digress) but there are some others out there on the market. If money's no object, I'd recommend the Thrustmaster Warthog. Whichever you choose, make sure the stick and throttle have buttons for you to bind some of the critical controls to (landing gear, airbrakes, countermeasures, etc.) The last thing you want to be doing in a dogfight is taking your hands off the throttle and stick to mash buttons on the keyboard to deploy chaff or flares.Having some sort of headtracking peripheral wil also go a long way to improving how immersed you are in the sim. It can be a bit of a pain having to use the mouse to look for enemies, especially if you're in an air-to-air fight. Another example is in A-10C, during a cold start, there's a couple of switches behind the throttle that you have to flip. These are normally obscured from the default viewing position, but if you have a TrackIR or something similar, you can "lean" down, see, and flip them accordingly. That said, DCS World is probably my absolute favorite game across the board. There's always something to do. You just have to be willing to put in the time to learn to fly.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 24, 2015
												Amazing game a must have, If you love Fighter simulators then your in for a treat, it has a big learning curve to it, but all in good time and practice you become a great fighter10/10Edit:That was my past review I thought well now Ive gotten the gyst of it let re-review it. inb4 long♥♥♥♥♥read hope it helpsFirstly you do not need to have a HOTAS Joystick and Throttle or rudder pedals, its a bit more difficult but its still do able. The First im gonna say 50+ Hours I played with my Logitech Extreme 3D Pro $40 Joystick (I live in Australia), I played Su-25T, FC3 and Partially A-10C. I played them all comfortably the only thing that was needed was to remember more keybindings etc for the A-10c and Su-25T, FC3 all the important stuff was able to be bound to my joystick regardless the point is, for a free simulator that has a amazing engine and crazy realism to it all you need is $40 for a joystick and any extra money for modules and you can play. I bought the HOTAS Warthog around 60 hours into the game still dont have rudder pedals but thats fine I just use the 'Z' and 'X' keys thats it, if you love Military aircraft and you plan on enlisting one day then install this game, do it you wont regret it, if you love a challenge this is the game for you. To lay it out ill put some pros and cons below.Pros:- The SU-25T and PF-51 Mustang are Free- The best Military Aviation Simulator on the market- Aircraft are being added all the time for example Leatherneck Sims is working on a F-14 Tomcat model which is gonna be amazing- All eras of Aircraft from 40's all the way to current.- FC3 is more of a easier version but still in relation to the realism flight.- Plenty of Single Player missions and servers to play on.- Graphics are beautiful on this game as well as the sound.- Performance is good even in MP, I have a 8 year old GPU and a Quad core CPU and with come custom settings and Mirrors off I get in SP 40-60 FPS and in MP 30-40 FPS- If you buy it from the website or steam you can still play with eachotherCons:- It has a big learning curve- There are only a few tutorial missions for standalone modules, there is no Tutorials on FC3, F-86F, Hawk only to name a few.- SP missions do tend to bug out sometimes not all the time- In the same sense that it is cheap it is also expensive with each module going for about $40+- not all of the modules are on Steam, the ones on the DCS website are available on there for a while before it gets released on Steam. For example 14 out of the 17 available modules are available on Steam not including terrains or campaigns.- You need Rudder pedals for rotary aircraft I tried and wasn't able to fly without themSo in short this is a great simulator it has its cons but its so worth it for the pros of the game. Some advice if you are thinking about spending $500 on a HOTAS Warthog, ask your self this are you going to make Simming a hobby or is it going to sit on your desk and collect dust? Simming is a expensive hobby so unless your going to use it dont bother. If you want to try the game out use a cheap joystick like the 3D Pro, if you are going to play moderately grab yourself a X55 Rhino it has HOTAS Functionality and so I have heard its a good joystick, if you know you are going to sim a fair bit at least 3-4 times a week and put hours into the game get the HOTAS Warthog and some rudderpedals. Also if you see the modules F-15C, SU-27, SU-25 and A-10A for DCS dont bother they are $10 each they are all included in Flamming Cliffs 3 Module as well as the MIG-29A, MIG-29S and SU-33.So do I recommend the game to everyone? Yes give it a try you may like itFor aviation enthusiasts? Why haven't you already installed thisFor people who want to make simming a hobby? Go buy a HOTAS and modules to your likingI absolutely love this Simiulator and if you love Military Aircraft you will too, I hoped this long♥♥♥♥♥essay helped in your desicion.

Posted: August 13, 2016
												If you have a Rift CV1, you need to try this sim out. One of the best VR experiences to date. With a HOTAS and rudder controls, it's out of this world. Be sure to set the display settings in the game's display options to the VR preset, otherwise you may experience some frame stuttering issues when you move your head around. Not only is the VR experience great, but the simulation physics and flight feel great. Haven't seen a flight sim this good since Falcon 4.0 or FSX.

content:
Posted: February 8, 2015
												DCS World 8/10     -OverallExpensive to some as you pay for individual aircraft. (Wait for sales to buy them)Amazing detailed aircraft in and out. Very technical, expect to do alot of reading or video watching to learn to operate all the systems in these aircraft.Joystick is a must for control, more so for heli's.     -Graphics Fairly typical of most modern simulator games these days but its More about the gameplay with DCS.Cockpit detail, and distant outside world looks good. Close up however trees and other objects are limited in detail.Again this game is more Simulator than eye candy.     -GameplayA game you will have to put some effort into to enjoyA learning curve for most.Amazing attention to detail. (eg very realistic wobble during intial rotor spinup on heli's)For true simulation lovers only.Have another device handy for looking stuff up.     -PerformanceDCS will push machines to get decent FPS with high or ultra settings.

												If you're looking for an arcade-y flight sim similar to Ace Combat or War Thunder, this isn't it. But if you're like me and you wanted a rich flying experience, DCS World brings that and much more to the table. I don't have nearly as many hours logged as some of the reviewers here but I can safely say that I'm hooked on this sim. In my opinion, the two must-have paid modules are Flaming Cliffs 3 and A-10C. FC3 is the bridge between the "arcade" and pure simulation aspects of DCS World, though it's by no means an arcade game at all. My preferred aircraft in FC3, the F-15, still requires a good deal of practice to get used to flying and fighting in, but once you have developed some proficiency with it, it's fantastic. It's always satisfying to go head-to-head with human opponents and actually have to work in order to get a kill.On the other hand, the A-10C is pure simulation. There's a lot of buttons and switches to learn, but if you do the training missions, you'll have a good foundation to work with. Do them a couple of times just to be sure you have a basic knowledge of what to do in certain situations and with certain weapons and flight systems.A couple of caveats: you can get a basic flight stick, but a HOTAS (Hands On Throttle And Stick) is highly recommended. I use a Saitek X55 (which has its own interesting quirks but I digress) but there are some others out there on the market. If money's no object, I'd recommend the Thrustmaster Warthog. Whichever you choose, make sure the stick and throttle have buttons for you to bind some of the critical controls to (landing gear, airbrakes, countermeasures, etc.) The last thing you want to be doing in a dogfight is taking your hands off the throttle and stick to mash buttons on the keyboard to deploy chaff or flares.Having some sort of headtracking peripheral wil also go a long way to improving how immersed you are in the sim. It can be a bit of a pain having to use the mouse to look for enemies, especially if you're in an air-to-air fight. Another example is in A-10C, during a cold start, there's a couple of switches behind the throttle that you have to flip. These are normally obscured from the default viewing position, but if you have a TrackIR or something similar, you can "lean" down, see, and flip them accordingly. That said, DCS World is probably my absolute favorite game across the board. There's always something to do. You just have to be willing to put in the time to learn to fly.

content:
Posted: January 16, 2016
												If your into SERIOUS combat flight sims you will LOVE this game!  That said...if you like the "pick up and play" style of flying games you will not like this.  You actually have to spend time with the manual and watching youtube vids to learn the systems of these aircraft to be effective in DCS.  It will take some time and effort....but theirs a huge feeling of satisfaction once you can command these aircraft effectively.  You feel like your in command of a real military war machine with all of its systems at your finger tips. There is a  game mode setting in DCS that simplifies everything to "pick up and play" style of simplicity. It makes the flight physics alot less realistic...and basically turns DCS into "Ace Combat" style of gameplay. Keep in mind every online multiplayer server thats worth anything (full of player)s to play competitvely DO NOT ALLOW "game mode". If your not playing DCS in full simulation mode then you will find it very difficult to play online.  All the most popular multiplayer servers ban "game mode"....even some of the more trivial game options are not allowed.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 8
												 This review is many years in the making. I got involved and DCS about five years ago, but just with in the last year I have gotten more serious in learning some of the aircraft I have purchased over the years.   It's takes time and patience to learn each individual aircraft.   You need to study manuals, and you need to do your own research.  I started with the A-10C but have become extremely attached to the BF109 K4 lately and spend most of my time dogfighting online.  This is by far the best sim out there, nothing compares.  Xplane 11 is a clunker compared to this game. (I own Xplane 11) I have purchased several modules on steam but I play the game via the most up to date version off of the DCS website and I also use 2.0 with the Nevada map.  Looking forward to the new Normandy map!  Love this game, well worth the $500 or so I have invested so far plus justified a 970 GTX purchase a couple years ago.  See you in the skies! (I'll be in your 6)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 3, 2016
												The best military flight simulator out there. But as many negative reviews show: this is not a game. It is a study sim with some gameplay elements on top. I started playing a few weeks ago and I greatly enjoy it. You will enjoy DCS World if:- you want to learn about aviation and want to understand how real military aircraft work- you enjoy reading 600+ page technical manuals, forums and wikipedia pages- you enjoy spending hours watching tutorial videos on youtube- you own a HOTAS, TrackIR and can memorize a lot of keyboard shortcuts- you have a lot of spare time - you enjoy steep learning curvesPersonally I love the experience. I currently have about 40 hours of game time logged (and have spent at least twice as much time reading manuals and watching tutorials). Yet I feel that I still have so much more to learn. It is awesome. I would definitely recommend DCS World (and especially the A-10C DLC) to people who know what they are getting themselves into. If you are looking for a relaxing game where you can jump into an airplane and shoot things, better look somewhere else.

content:
Posted: February 10, 2016
												If you're a fan of Flight Simulation and you're looking for a thrilling combat experience, then DCS is the one you should choose. No other software would be able to provide you more realism and get you closer to what a fighter pilot really feels aboard those powerful machines. The numerous controls are hard to handle at first and I recommend you to read the flight manuals to familiarize yourself with the numerous instruments available to you. The tutorials are too basic and don't allow you to put in practice what you've just learned as they are just a bunch of videos. So the flight manuals are really not a luxury you should pass. Dont worry they are free but It would take some hours to read it all as it's pretty consistent.On a personal note I'm not pushing for gender equality but if you could add a female voice for the pilot I would gladly appreciate that. ;)

												This game is really fun to play with some of the DLC's.If you like simulation games, or realism shooters, that kind of stuff this is a game for you!It has the most realistic simulation in flying fighter jets by far.It also has this for helicopters and other vehicle's.You will get emersed into the game and have a great time with friends.It has some downside's like all games and for me they are:If you do not know anything about planes or helicopters and stuff, don't buy it unless you want to learn, this game is alot about learning new things.If you do not have a joystick, defenetly don't buy it, unless you are getting one, it's pretty much unplayable without a joystick. and i mean to get the full simulation you need atleast a joystickIt can get a little hard remembering all the keybindings, and you might need to print out some pre flight check manuals, or just startup manuals if you are new cause its a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥to alt+tab this game.Overall its a really fun game and best flight simulator i've played so far.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 16, 2016
												If your into SERIOUS combat flight sims you will LOVE this game!  That said...if you like the "pick up and play" style of flying games you will not like this.  You actually have to spend time with the manual and watching youtube vids to learn the systems of these aircraft to be effective in DCS.  It will take some time and effort....but theirs a huge feeling of satisfaction once you can command these aircraft effectively.  You feel like your in command of a real military war machine with all of its systems at your finger tips. There is a  game mode setting in DCS that simplifies everything to "pick up and play" style of simplicity. It makes the flight physics alot less realistic...and basically turns DCS into "Ace Combat" style of gameplay. Keep in mind every online multiplayer server thats worth anything (full of player)s to play competitvely DO NOT ALLOW "game mode". If your not playing DCS in full simulation mode then you will find it very difficult to play online.  All the most popular multiplayer servers ban "game mode"....even some of the more trivial game options are not allowed.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 30, 2016
												The worst thing about this game are the prices for the more in-depth cockpits, but most likely if you spend that much on them in the first place, it will be very worth it. DCS is nothing short of amazing. It feels awesome to fly the planes, the learning curve is there, but after a few days, it's all down and good. The planes have weight to them, and even the simplest of maneuvers and procedures can't be done by just jumping in and acting like you know what you're doing.If you aren't an experienced pilot, no worries. You can start with circling airfields and landing at others, move onto some strafing runs, go to bombings, SEAD, and by then, you'll probably have purchased FC3.Speaking of FC3, researching the expansion will likely tell you that you need the others, which isn't true anymore. It's an awesome expansion for learning to fly. FC3 is basically the bridge between the SU-25 and aircraft like the A-10C.It's a great game, and it's free to start off. If you like aircraft, whether it be FSX, ArmA, IL-2, or any other simulator, you will like this game.*Also, even though the photos show the SU-24, and some other planes, you cannot fly any planes that aren't A). the SU-25T, or B). listed in a DLC.*

content:
Posted: April 11, 2016
												As a simulator, the fidelity is amazing. Everything is reconstituted in game from the tiniest details in the cockpit to the slightest nuances in aircraft behavior. Even compared to other simulators on the market, DCS is top-notch and possibly the only modern simulator to allow modern-day air-to-air combat in addition to a decent selection of older jets ranging from the skies of Vietnam, Korea and WWII.Pros:- Beautiful graphics- Supremely realistic- Good selection of aircraft- Good selection of single player modes, campaigns, and settings- Relatively healthy multiplayerCons:- Somewhat hard to get into for beginners- Not all aircraft have a tutorial section- High cost of individual aircraft- Modern air-superiority jets basically require TrackIR or equivalent to efficiently operate the off-bore sights

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 21, 2016
												A true flight sim for any pilot enthusiest, especially if you are considering a military career. this isn't a game that u just jump into and expect to start flying. you need a basic understanding of flight instruments. if u get an add-on with a clickable cockpit, you will have to spend hours going through the training courses just to know how to start and operate the aircraft systems. you really cannot claim to master any aircraft without putting at least the standard of 40 flight hours into each aircraft. The sense of accomplishment as u struggle with one apect, then turn it into an easy task, is what keeps me playing. When u get that perfect 3-point touchdown with the p-51, then start doing it over and over, u really feel like its a major acheivement. At this point, i only have 50 hours on the game, and i still feel like a noob. im very confident with the p-51 now and ill be going into the A-10 add-on next. As to physics, i cannot say whether they are absolutely realistic or not, but i am highly impressed. If u put the time into the game and really try to learn how to fly, thats when u get the entertainment factor out of it. It greatly helps to buy a dlc with clickable cockpit also and i will tell any pilot enthusiest to get this game.

content:
Posted: July 25, 2015
												Absolutely the best flight experience available on the PC.Here are some considerations:-It is a *simulator,* don't expect an arcade experience, even in the simple flight modes.-Combat is very real, and therefore very difficult.  Success is very satisfying, but be willing to take the time to learn how to succeed.-Despite some reviews the platform is exceptionally stable and functional, but the user interface is not intuitive (that's to be expected considering the scope of the simulation).  Again, it will take some time to learn.-Multiplayer is super fun, but know that it's a session-based environment, not open world.-Some modules (aircraft) will offer more content and detail than others, so do a little research before you purchase, and only purchase aircraft you are genuinely interested in flying.If you're a fan of aviation simulations, patient, and willing to learn, you will thoroughly enjoy your experience with DCS world.

content:
Posted: January 21, 2015
												The two free aircraft that you get are very fun to fly, and decent to introduce the game to you. This is a combat flight simulator with a command element to give the ground units more realism. I highly recommend this game to anyone who is interested in aviation, or flying aircraft. This game does have a slightly steep learning curve, but that is countered by video tutorials available at the main menu of the game. I highly recommend that you visit the developers website, and download a copy of the checklist for the aircraft that you wish to fly. Then print it out and keep it handy, or download it to a tablet. The graphics are not bad for a flight simulator, but are not cutting edge. The multiplayer is not bad, but depends on the server and its mission. Most multiplayer missions are community developed, and not all aircraft are available in every mission. Their is also no in game VoIP feature, so downloading Teamspeak is a must for voice communication. All and all a good game, but better if you pick it up during a sale.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 19, 2014
												I am not an expert on flight simulators by any stretch of the imagination, so fair warning, I may be naive or ignorant in my assessment of this game. That said, by far I believe DCS World, and what I have seen of its addons including DCS: A-10C Warthog, to be the most comprehensive and realistic modern combat flight simulator series I have ever seen. Many thanks to the developers for making the base game available for free on Steam. There's a lot included in DCS World to appeal to both the hardcore flight simulation crowd and to educators.There are some minor omissions and simplifications from DCS World's default aircraft model, the Su-25, compared to its DLC packages in terms of the compexity of the cockpit's controls and graphical complexity, but what is available is so impressive to me I can't complain. Even this simplified model is more complex than many flight sims I've experienced in the past.It's a good sign that some of the original companies which designed aircraft featured in this series are assisting with the development of the game/simulator, alongside the usual industry veterans. The sound design, user interface design, controls, mission editor and scripting system all seem to be quite well-executed. The game supports flightsticks, HOTAS and TrackIR, as well as (a rather inappropriate method of control in my opinion) the Microsoft Xbox 360 Controller alongside a mouse and keyboard.I've not yet completely explored what the game has to offer in terms of difficulty levels, or rather, aircraft simulation settings, but my advice is that people who are looking for a casual, pick-up-and-go flight simulator should do their research or probably look elsewhere, as the game may be far more complex than expected. That said, you can't beat the price, so I would insist that you test the game out and see what you think of it first. There's plenty of tutorials in-game as well as available on the Internet to help you become accustomed to the Su-25's basic startup/taxi/takeoff/landing procedures and usage in combat.If you are interested in online multiplayer, there is a thriving community of DCS World players online these days. I bet there's a wingman available to help you out.Overall, at a first impression I consider DCS World and its expansions to be an excellent value for its cost. I look forward to buying the expansions.

content:
Posted: July 27, 2016
												Hello, this is my DCS World Review ^-^Before I get started, I am a huge jet and ww2 aircraft fanThis game puts my Knowledge of aircraft to shamePros:Super realistic damage and flight modelsActive playersBeautiful graphics (even on low, as my computer isn't the best I run it on low)Updated oftenLegendary planes such as the Bf 109, P-51, Fw 190, F-86, MiG-15bis, MiG-21, and even the F-15Cons: Optimization could be betterVery steep learning curveConfusing tutorialsPrices for extra aircraft are very expensivePull 1G in the Su25 "Frogfoot" and get complained at in Russian Requires lots of patience, time and effortPractically requires a joystickAll in all, amazing game, if you've got a beast computer, I highly recommend this game!9/10 would rip my wings and catch fire immediately in a Tf-51 (P51D ground attack variant)

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 29, 2016
												Where to begin....I've owned this game since the beginning. Loved Flaming Cliffs, etc..bought Blachshark when it came out. Very difficult, steep learning curve and I played it here and there, then I got an Oculus Rift and everything changed.....Suddenly I'm sitting in the cockpit of these planes looking around, these that I've dreamed of flying, looking at pictures as a kid (there where naked girls too but I've always loved stuff that flies). Now I can't get enough and I've got several of the planes figured out. What a difference a nice VR headset makes.My only ctriticism of DCS is the trainging missions aren't consistent. Some are great and narrated like the A10, others are not narrated, one set is narrated in Russian (maybe I have a head start for when trump sells us to Russia?), it has English text at least. I noticed also in some training missions, mapped controls don't line up with the directions. I've been able to work around it all. It just feels like they all should run through a scrubbing/standardization process before it's released.That said I can't get enough, steep learning curve warning though, it's very realistic. Tons of hours and I still rarely get through a mission end to end without crashing.

												I have read  in a couple places and they keep talking about adding motion control support for Vive. When exactly will this happnen? I know people think that it would not work but have you playde Time Machine? The motion controllers work fine with it. The left controller is your flight stick, im sure it can be programed easily for DCS. The right stick can be many things, has anyone tried Universe Sandbox? With a key press on left stick where the grip is, you can open up a display on top of the left stick without giving up control of the flight and select menus or selections using your right controller. The right controller can also be used to virtually touch the switches and turn knobs all by holding down the trigger and using the motion of turning or pushing. Posted: April 10, 2014
												The DCS World SoftWare is Amazing, you get a Free SU-25t Fighter Jet, but once you add the A-10c WartHog, it's the most accurate and challenging Figher AirCraft Simulator I've ever used, keep in mind that the developers created the A-10c Simulator for the Army & AirForce for training, so you can imaging how intense it is... but don't expect to learn it right off the bat, you need to read the A-10c Flight Manual, and the A-10c GUI Manual, also do all the Training Missions to get familiar with the AirCraft, but, for those that just want a casual Jet Fighter Game, there is a "GameMode Physics" and different setting for G-Force, and Radio Assists, as well as becoming Invincible, UnLimited Fuel, UnLimited Weapons, etc...I highly recommend the DCS World coupled with the A-10c WartHog Add-On Module

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 8, 2014
												A truly evolving combat flight simulation. The platform started as Lock on: modern air combat in 2003. Since then, the developer decided to part ways with Ubisoft and successfully made a niche for themselves. DCS world is the "World of tanks" for modern flight simulation. Its still in its infancy with the scope. Things are constantly being updated/added and it has become a premier flight simulation. The graphics engine is dated with more CPU intensive processes, but the engine is due for a change with a revolutionary new EDGE (Eagle Dynamics Graphic Engine) that should be released this year. The planes are represented in painstaking detail. The physics for each plane is the most accurate representation in any flight simulation, including military trainers.The base game is free and allows you to fly the Su-25T and TF-51D. But the others can be purchased through addons. There are two lines of DCS addons:DCS: xxxx  :: Fully detailed aircraft including clickable cockpits. You need to spend 3-5 min just starting up the aircraft. Just like pilots in real life.DCS: xxxx Flaming cliffs :: A study simulation. There are easy one button presses to get the systems/avionics going, but the aircraft physics is still modelled very much like the DCS counterparts.At the end of the day, this is one of those MUST PLAY SIMULATIONS if you like flying aircraft. They still have a way to go with limited campaigns, dated graphics etc.. but things are improving with every version.Gameplay: 8/10Graphics: 7/10Audio: 7/10Replayability: 9/10MUST PLAY. ENDLESS HOURS OF ENTERTAINMENT.

content:
Posted: May 6, 2014
												I have never in my life been as challenged in playing a game as i have in this one. At times it feels like you can't do something or that a city is simply too well defended by SAMs. And just when you feel as though you are defeated and can no longer complete your mission, you decide to ask for some help. and everyone is extremely helpful. It doesnt matter if you are a vet or a new pilot people always help out and (almost) never put others down. I love this game with a passion. The fact that the aircraft are 1:1 replicas including flight models is amazing! There is a plane for every job and no 1 plane can do it all, it truly is a team effort to win. I give this game a solid 10/10!

content:
Posted: February 23, 2014
												DCS world is a great sim. However it does have a huge learning curve, for those who like the hard core sim where every buttion and switch is modeled in the aircraft look no further! lucky for people who aren't so hard core there is the Flaming cliffs 3 module although this module still takes a bit to figure out how to use the planes some you tube vids and some button mapping to a good quality joystick and dogfighting is a blast! FC3 adds the f15C, su-27, these planes are pretty easy to fly (you dont have to pull 20 switches to fire a cannon). After playing a bit in FC3 and finally getting the hang of radar and beyond vis fighting I found DCS FC3 to be and enjoyable and challanging sim, dodging Heat seekers by dropping flares and pulling hard 7-9G turns only to have the missile pass beneath the belly of the aircraft by a factor of meters is such a rush, and then winning your first airvictory and then your first combat sortie is somthing that instills a sort of pride in you.TL;DR: DCS world modules like A-10C,BLACK SHARK 2, and other stand alone planes are more suited to the hard core players (even though there is a game mode it's not very well explained) FC3 with a small amount of learning can be a rewarding and fun module for the Sim junkie. (ps look up youtube tutorials as they tend to explain how to use the systems better i found this one helped alot with the F-15 


YouTube™ Video: DCS World Lock On Flamming cliff 3 F-15C Start Up and Combat Basic Tutorial 

			Views: 70,298

 however don't try to learn it all at once, you won't reamember and become frustrated!)

content:
Posted: June 19, 2014
												DCS is not for those not willing to learn how to operate aircraft by the book. I currently have all but four of the modules for DCS and find the ammount of detail put into the systems of each aircraft amazing. I find it awesome that I can get into my MI-8 and start it up per the actual aircraft's checklist and then operate it like the real thing. The graphics are great, especially the aircraft textures, considering that the game is growing in age. Hopefully we will see the release of the new EDGE engine soon and the graphics will be back up to par. I highly recommend this simulator for flight enthusiasts, combat flight enthusiasts, or even casual gamers, because you can tweak the options to suit that style of play. It is however much more fun and more of a challenge to try and learn the systems when in full realism mode.
